comments.commentBody:
Gail hits at the heart of this catastrophe which is plain old home grown ignorance.

Those once ranting the loudest against Obama and demon Government back in their local barber shops and social gatherings have been enabled by the largesse of the Koch brothers and other vested interests and ultimately elected as U.S. representatives of their local gerrymandered fiefs.

Now, with no real idea of national politics, rational debate or other basics, they have packed up their anger and their ignorance and moved into paneled offices in our nation's Capitol.

How do the 30-some-odd newbie zealots at the heart of this mini fission reaction taking place in the aging GOP reactor be made to see the damage they are doing? Or must we actually suffer a full national meltdown and long lasting damage to our country before some rational Republican leadership stops this?

There clearly seem to be no statesmen left up there to deal with this vapid Congress and its shameful game of hostage-taking political chicken. Ultimately they must all eat crow.

Larry Ray
www.larryray.com

This is just a bit silly: "Whereas tribalistic and collectivist societies do not distinguish between natural laws and social customs"!!!

This isn't so silly: "The right wing is associated with ... a radical skepticism that condemns modern, secular, scientific existence in favor of an imaginary past".

During the general strike in UK during the depression of the 1930's Churchill rejected the idea of negotiations with the strike leaders as non-negotiation was critical to saving a constitutional electoral system. If the government gave into blackmail the system would no longer be one where elections decided who rules but power went to the street, unions, mob passions; as happens in France, and to passionate minorities as in the House of Representatives.

Whereas tribalistic and collectivist societies do not distinguish between natural laws and social customs, so that individuals are unlikely to challenge traditions they believe to have a sacred or magical basis, the beginnings of an open society are marked by a distinction between natural and man-made religious belief).[5]law, and an increase in personal responsibility and accountability for moral choices (not incompatible with religion)

The plot is about social status and identity rather than policy. The policy discussions followed by the media pundits are not the irrational stillness as it appears. The right wing is associated with extreme pessimism and a radical skepticism that condemns modern, secular, scientific existence in favor of an imaginary past, before uppity gays, blacks and women appeared in today's complex realities.
But they hate atheists.  Go figure.
I bet most of the Republican base, which has a fetish for paying its "representatives" to exploit them, don't even know who Ayn Rand is.  This is what we are dealing with here.
Ayn Rand was an atheist who believed in the "freedom" of a woman to procure an abortion for herself. In this wise, she is far more of a libertarian that those who themselves such--like Rand Paul.

It's a ghoulish experience watching Republicans blow their own brains out like this. But the pain of this government shutdown might be a worthy sacrifice to purge our government of the whack jobs who have made a delusional, antisocial crackpot like Ayn Rand their hero. And here's exactly where they are coming from:

"There can be no compromise between freedom and government controls; to accept 'just a few controls' is to surrender the principle of inalienable individual rights and to substitute for it the principle of the government's unlimited, arbitrary power, thus delivering oneself into gradual enslavement. As an example of this process, observe the present domestic policy of the United States."

– Ayn Rand, The Virtue of Selfishness, "Doesn't Life Require Compromise?" (1961, p. 68)

Yes, they really believe this stuff.
This is the culmination of Reagan's' war on government.

The federal government shutdown is real and it is no game. Some of the very real and damaging consequences:

--800,000 people laid off, and a million more-- including the Capitol Hill police who protected the House and Senate during Thursday's lockdown-- working without pay.

--The disruption of the production and dissemination of important economic and demographic data. One example: U.S. monthly unemployment data, normally scheduled for release on October 4, 2013, did not appear. Business and economic analysts depend on this and similar information on making investment and other decisions.

--The disruption of services to the poor that rely on federal funding. One example is Head Start preschool programs.

--The curtailment of airline safety checks that rely on federal inspections.

--Erosion of the U.S.'s international reputation. Media in other nations are frankly incredulous that much of the U.S. government has been put out of business.

--All told, the shutdown is estimated to cost the U.S. economy $200 million a day, meaning that we'll reach the $1 billion mark by the end of the day on Saturday, October 5.

My household relies on the income of a currently furloughed federal worker. We're fortunate to have some savings, but a lengthy shutdown would hurt us as it will many hard-working American families. It's easy for those who aren't affected to reduce the shutdown to a matter of political gamesmanship, but all too many of us don't have that luxury.

suejean, you've rendered me helpless.

I'm happy to give you a little extra latitude.
I thought that bit about 54' 40" and 'extra latitude' was pretty funny, but Hey...
It was unparalleled, Leapy.

This puzzle illustrates all of the points we discussed in yesterday's blog and then some. On first pass I filled in almost nothing except IBM, DAHL and AAHS. Taking a break in the middle was immensely helpful -- upon returning,I immediately "saw" KOMODODRAGONS and EPRITDECORPS. I learned that cigarette papers are made from FLAX (why didn't I know that before?) and Apple's clever address. We have yet another meaning for "draws" - that's something like 6 this week in 3 puzzles. Enjoyed figuring out ALGORE and MANX CAT. Had to really work to understand AIM, but I got it. And nice to see ROO clued uniquely, if obliquely. I'd list all of the very clever clues, but I'd run out of allowed characters in my post. Admirable puzzle all around.

Ms Fan, suejean is not a BRIT. Susan, Happy Birthday! Deadline, maybe you can cheer Hazel up by calling her Stubbins and offering something like scrambled egg or cheese or vanilla ice cream, all favorites of my past cats. (My Morris look-alike Lincoln loved spaghetti with meat sauce above all else.)

The situation is not symmetric. The Democrats want to enlarge the Fed gov while the Republicans want to shrink it. I like ObamaCare, but it is a fact that it is an enlargement of the Fed gov.

The Constitution was designed for a determined and substantial minority to stop the Fed gov in its track. The implicit premise was that State govs should be running most of the gov business.

The Fed gov had two major expansions. The first one was decided by the civil war and the major issues of that war are not controversial today. The second was FDR's new deal. This one is very controversial. It also involves relations between the Fed and State govs.

One may or may not like it, but these are the facts.

"Who gains from this debacle?" That is the question, isn't it?

Aren't the Koch Brothers invested in the stock market that is struggling? Aren't they losing more than we mere mortals every time it goes down?

Usually it is fairly straightforward to follow the money, but this time, I wonder just who it is that is making money on the shutdown--or is someone playing a "long game" and taking a hit now so that he wins big later?

Agree 100%.  But about your guests.  There is a helicopter service that takes people down into the canyon itself.  That might be an option.  Never been there myself but have seen stunning pictures.  Try contacting the principal of the reservation school down there.  As far as I know, they should have an exempt status and so will be open.

Why does Arizona vote Republican?

After the recent devastating floods in northeast Colorado, having the Republicans shut down Rocky Mountain National Park has only made our economic situation worse, but they don't care. They call it a haircut.

At the high school where I teach, we have just welcomed several German foreign exchange students and their English teacher  who were anticipating visiting the Grand Canyon.  Every time I visit the Canyon I meet visitors from all over the world who admire our park system and love America.   How humiliating that this world treasure is closed to our guests because of the chicanery and stupidity of our right wing lunatic fringe and their deep-pocketed paymasters.  We stand to lose our tourist industry again - just when we were beginning to recover from our pariah status with SB1070. Who gains from this debacle?
I should have mentioned that emus also come in mobs.  I believe we already suspected that.
Thanks Kiki. I think I was thinking of how crows mob birds of prey. You're right, it is murder. Thanks for the link.
I think meerkats travel in mobs too.  If I'm remembering correctly from "Meerkat Manor."
I learned that kangaroos, like crows, come in mobs. Nice tough puzzle. Slow solve that came in fits and starts. Well done.
But they hate atheists.  Go figure.

This is just a bit silly: "Whereas tribalistic and collectivist societies do not distinguish between natural laws and social customs"!!!

This isn't so silly: "The right wing is associated with ... a radical skepticism that condemns modern, secular, scientific existence in favor of an imaginary past".
The wisdom of Lincoln in regard to the current crisis of governance is inexhaustible.

Fantastic post, 3Bells!

Regarding suejean: I once enquired as to whether she is a subject of Her Majesty, but it was a late reply and she may not have seen it. I know that earlier in the week she self-identified as a YANK but I suppose her fellow Yorkshireans (Yorkshonians? Yorkwegians?) would refer to her as such, affectionately, even if she had become a UK citizen.

suejean, I'm sorry if I erroneously said that BRIT was a shout-out to you; and can you please tell us what the acceptable group terms are for kangaroos (the common animals, I have noticed, often have more than one acceptable group term) (also, is there a better phrase than "group term" for a word such as "exaltation" in "exaltation of larks"?).

Fortunately, the harmonious 3Bells has provided me with the opportunity to say that I count RCMP as a shout-out to our many Canadian colleagues, even those who were just passing through ... pecantart, Robert (& Elke), Leapfinger, tudor, and all the rest whose peaceable nature for lo these past almost-two centuries allows us to maintain such a long undefended border, so we can overstaff our Southern border with Border Guards! Plus their country took in all those GIs in transit in WWII, and the survivors of the Titanic, until they could get where they were going.

And, Robert MacNeil.

tish tosh. I know more than one person with a net worth over 5 million who cares quite a lot for the 99% and probably considers themselves to be part of it because that's where they came from. Some people have scrimped and saved and invested their entire life to come up with that kind of money. It didn't fall out of the sky and thonk them on the head. And in the US where a catastrophic illness could wipe that out AND MORE, it could boil down to peanuts.

On the other hand, I know people who have 100K stashed in a savings account who imagine they are part of the ruling elite.

Not all people with a little money are ugly and selfish. We need to differentiate between the ruling elite and the regular guy.

Bmcg - Congress does not get free healthcare. This is a myth. They and other federal workers are treated just like the workers at any large corporation. They get a choice of plans with monthly payments, copays and deductibles. The government pays for part just as the corporations do.

The only diference is that Congress gets the samr plan as the average workers. In corporations the executives get Ferrari plans

Here's the American system of government. First, everything and everybody is bought because there are no restrictiions on campaign contributions. People go to Congress not for love of country or passion for the common good, but as a waystop to the real money in lobbying.
The politicians fiercest in denunciation of special interests are the ones most bought by special interests.
Representatives draw their own district maps with one thought in mind: loading the opposition into concentrated pockets while dispersing their own party support to maximize seats. Hence the Repub majority. Legislative rules obstruct anything ever been done.
But that's OK because the only people who count are those with net worths over $5 m and they are happy with nothing been done for the other 99 per cent.
The pols pass budgets. Then they have a separate vote to see if they are willing to pay back the money they've borrowed.
Taxes are near the lowest for rich democracies but the tax squaking the greatest. Infrastructure crumbles, education deteriorates; child poverty the highest; military spending larger than the rest of the world combined; incarceration the highest; world leaders in disbelief in science; life expectancy low; preventable disease high.

And in this stew the most vile legislation ever is a modest effort to expand health coverage and control its costs, which are by far the highest.
Ted Cruz should be grateful to the millions of Democrats who pray for his presidential nomination.
Teachers do it too, on much more limited budgets than most lawyers have.

"It is also clear that the President cannot give in to this extortion."

This is happening because the Republicans were so certain that Obama would give in. He has compromised, often before even talking, too many times before. They took him for granted. They also believed their own lies about Obama being even weaker than he has been.

This is the price of Republican intransigence. That intransigence is the price of past surrender to ever-escalating bad behavior.

The very sad reality of this situation is that the only person who has the power to end this debacle is the Speaker of the House. He can, and should be duty bound to, bring the Senate CR before the entire House for an up or down vote. This was the consideration given the resolutions the House sent to the Senate. The speaker only has to abandon the Hastert rule (which isn't a rule at all) and allow the full house to speak. The clean CR will pass and this idiocy will end. But John Boehner is the only person who has the power to do so. And since the debt ceiling issue will be piled on in 12 days it seems that he is the only one person that can take any action that will protect the American people.

It is also clear that the President cannot give in to this extortion. The Republicans have shown time and time again that they cannot be trusted to act responsibly. Any concession granted by the administration will only be used to further shackle the American people with the chains of austerity. This cannot be allowed to happen.

Although I agree with her on issues, it is only fair that I correct Michele's inaccurate characterization.

Michele (and all others out there who join the online political debate on the side of reason and sanity): Please do not risk diminishing your credibility by asserting that President Obama was reelected "by a large margin"? Thanks.

Yes, the President's "nationwide popular vote" (NPV) margin over Gov. Romney was greater than the 1790 U.S. population; and yes, Obama's dominance of states in the Pacific Time Zone made his reelection obvious before Karl Rove even thought to deny the anticipated outcome on live TV.

But for an incumbent winning a Presidential election, he did not have a "large" percentage margin in either the NPV nor the Electoral College.

The President's 329 Electors resulted from about 51% of the NPV, against Romney's 47% (I really, REALLY like that number -- "47%"), for a margin of about 4%. ALL other re-elected Presidents had larger margins, except in 1916 and 2004. (I will defer to Ms. Collins regarding 1892, won by Grover Cleveland ... non-consecutively.)

Truman won by 4.48%, and people thought he had lost!

Obama's 61% of Electors makes his re-election more resounding than 1812's, 1916's, 1948's, and 2004's, but even ex-Pres. Cleveland in 1892 topped 62%.

What matters is: the GOP LOST the Presidency, 8 House seats (because only 47% of voters nationwide voted for a GOP House candidate) and 2 Senate seats (42%, nationwide).

Just the facts, ma'am!

They completely ignored the fact we reelected him by a large margin.    They will not be able to ignore it when Obamacare turns out to be a resoundling success.  That they shut down the government to prevent.   A huge misinformation campaign exposed.  Let's get back to fixing the problems this country faces.  I'd like to take advantage of the next 3 years we have with a pretty amazing president.

This guy looks pretty cool:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_W._Fairbanks

AL GORE
OSCARS
ASIMOV
DODGERS
The Beach Boys
Jason Mraz

No excuse for no avatar.

You are most fortunate to have found one another and have had the opportunity to show others the essence of true love and devotion. G-d ordained that you were soul mates and would be able to only find the good in each other.  Mazal tov!

Typically if I have trouble sleeping it will be after I have slept 4 or 5 hours. So I get up and draw a line down a center of a page.
On the left side at the top I write " What is bugging me ? "
On the right side at the top I write "What can I do about it right now?"
I fill it out. The ones I can't do anything about right then I write, " Nothing" . The others , I write what I can do and do it immediately and go back to bed and go right back to sleep.
Hard to object to it, but the GOP would go nuts after all the playoffs from drug companies.

While I really do not want to see the President or
Democratic members of Congress engaging
in negotiations with the T-Party extortionist over
the passage of the Continuing Resolution to
fund the government or on raising the Debt
Ceiling there is one concession I would like
to see the President make:

I would like the President to make an offer
to the T-Partiers/Boehner faction that he
would support the repeal of the restriction
on Medicare negotiating the price of
medications available under
Medicare Part D.

This would allow a face saving path for the
T-Partiers/Boehner faction to demonstrate
to the American People that their actions
were truly motivated by the best interest
of the country.
"The peasants" are flooding the websites and buying health insurance under the Plan.  "The peasants" love it, putting their money where their mouths are.

What evidence supports your last sentence, Gail?  I hear the president and his men war whooping, journalists cheering them on, and vulnerable Republicans nervously trimming their hedges.  But nothing at all from us peasants.  (Comments posted on elitist media sites don't count--the other side has its equal and opposite version of the same thing. If the peasants actually were gathering on street corners, this would mark an historic shift.  But what I see is the passivity that has reigned for almost two generations now, which I interpret as bone-deep resignation to continued rule by great wealth working through the mannequins we call politicians.

I thought it was a murder of crows. Maybe those are just the hitmen and the higher ups are in the mob.

You can find a gallimaufry of those terms here:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_collective_nouns

I agree with you, it's over for the opponents of the ACA. The question is how much damage they will cause while fighting to the last man. We've seen some unconscionable things: encouraging young people to go naked without insurance, and denial of service attacks on exchanges that are preventing other people from signing up.

I hope the meanness of this disgusting episode becomes common knowledge. Then it will be all over for the GOP, and it's well past time for that.
Just because people are using the exchanges to sign up for insurance doesn't mean that they like the law. We will find out in 2014 what they really think.

Interest is more than predicted even by the friends of the health care law.

This is a huge vote against the Republicans on health care, in form of "voting with their feet" or "putting their money where their mouth is."

This is the sort of voting that means a lot more than any poll. Poll questions can shape the results, but their is no shaping this. People given the choice are going of this in overwhelming numbers.

This is the end of the fight. The Republicans lost. They may not realize it yet, but it is over.

Pulling "completely" out of AF is/and will be a massive effort that will take some time mostly based on the logistics of such a withdrawal and ensuring security of the forces conducting it. As mentioned in the article, another consideration concerns our NATO partners who will also withdraw should the U.S. opt for the "zero option".

And let it be the beginning of a total U.S. withdrawal from military presence and military commitments in all of Asia. We do not need another Vietnam, another Afghanistan, another iraq or another (God help us) Korean War.
Asians must be left alone to sort out their own problems in their own way.
It is not only American children that are being killed.  Many more Afghan children have been killed, a large number by American forces.  Shouldn't that also be a reason to withdraw?

If they are not happy with us, lets go home.
Why wait till 2014, today is just fine.
Spend the money here at home and stop having our children killed for military industrial profit.

Mr Alverson: I can assure you that this time it is not about money. It is something that money can't buy, trust me! Instead you should worry about the consequences of a complete U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan, which has not much left to lose. But the U.S. and its European allies will lose big if anything goes wrong at the negotiation table. What the Afghan side want are legitimate demands of the Afghan people and no puppet is to be found to agree to anything else. It is very simple: The U.S., particularly Britain, will have to choose between Afghanistan-India and Pakistan. I personally think that the Brits will influence U.S. decision making and they will  choose Pakistan. Therefore Afghans and westerners can then kiss each other goodby.

Oh no! The US is going to have to fully pull out of Afghanistan WHat a shock. I thought we could stay there forever - just like the brits and soviets did. Maybe if we give them more money we can stay. Please, please Brer Fox, said Brer Rabbit, don't throw me in that briar patch.
